question_details.title: Will the study of oral rehydration solution and zinc distribution in Sierra Leone find a statistically significant increase in ORS/zinc usage by the recipients?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2024-10-23 16:00:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/28373). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

According to [GiveWell](https://www.givewell.org/research/grants/wageningen-university-sierra-leone-rct-2024):

>In May 2024, GiveWell made a $676,857 grant to Wageningen University to include additional components to a randomized controlled trial (RCT) of door-to-door health service delivery in remote communities in Sierra Leone. Non-GiveWell funding was already covering one round of service delivery and surveys, including the provision of routine childhood and HPV vaccines, vitamin A supplements, and deworming pills. This grant will add chlorine, for disinfecting drinking water, and oral rehydration solution (ORS) and zinc, for treating dehydration due to diarrhea, to the bundle of health services that will be delivered, and will support a second round of service delivery and surveys 3 months after the initial round.

GiveWell estimates that reduction in diarrhea deaths via chlorine and ORS/zinc could raise the cost-effectiveness estimate of health commodities distribution programs like this one, if usage is high.

The study's design is as follows:

>The study will be a cluster-randomized RCT in which the treatment communities receive household-to-household visits from health teams offering routine childhood and HPV vaccines to those who have not received all of the vaccines in the vaccination schedule. Households with children under the age of 5 will also be offered VAS, deworming pills, chlorine to treat drinking water, and ORS/zinc to treat future diarrhea episodes. Control communities will not receive any interventions. The health teams will also provide information on when young children are due for subsequent vaccines. The health teams will return after three months and provide the same bundle of services.

Results of the study, if a statistically significant increase can be shown, will have implications for GiveWell’s future funding of similar interventions:
>GiveWell is considering supporting programs that deliver vaccines to communities far from public health facilities, as one strategy to increase vaccination coverage in areas with high vaccine-preventable disease burdens. Chlorine and ORS/zinc, if usage rates are reasonably high, have the potential to increase the cost-effectiveness of such programs. (More [here](https://www.givewell.org/research/grants/wageningen-university-sierra-leone-rct-2024#We_expect_this_study_to_have_a_decent_chance_of_affecting_our_future_grant_decisions).)

In the grant rationale, GiveWell explains some potential reasons the study might fail:

- Recipients might be overwhelmed by the quantity of health services they’re receiving (childhood vaccines, HPV vaccines, VAS, deworming) and not process instructions on ORS/zinc usage. 
- Recipients might not use either ORS/zinc or chlorine if they view these commodities as substitutes for each other. 
- People in areas with very little contact with health systems might react to health information or commodities differently than people in other areas.

In its own internal forecasting, GiveWell predicts a 70% chance that the study measures a statistically significant increase in ORS/zinc usage in the treatment group over the two rounds of distribution.

For more context on the commodity being distributed, see also the GiveWell report: [Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) and Zinc
](https://www.givewell.org/international/technical/programs/oral-rehydration-solution-zinc)

This question resolves as **Yes** if, before January 1, 2026, the GiveWell-funded [study](https://www.givewell.org/research/grants/wageningen-university-sierra-leone-rct-2024) by Wageningen University and its affiliated research team finds a statistically significant increase in oral rehydration solution (ORS) and zinc usage by the treatment group over two rounds of distribution of ORS/zinc to certain household clusters in Sierra Leone, compared with the control group. 

If no statistically significant increase is found, whether because none occurred, there is insufficient data, or the study is not completed before January 1, 2026, this question resolves as **No**.

In assessing the statistical significance in the comparison between the control group and treatment group, please note that the p-value must be <0.05.

**Two new studies predict results of declining MMR uptake, restricting non-medical vaccine exemptions**
A modeling study led by University of Texas researchers estimated that a 5% decline in kindergarten MMR vaccination would markedly increase measles outbreak sizes in Texas counties. Using a mathematical model calibrated with local vaccination rates and case data from Gaines County, the study projected that under a baseline scenario (current rates) Gaines and Walker counties would see 14 measles cases per 1,000 people, while a 5% reduction would raise cases to 21 per 1,000 in Gaines and 16 per 1,000 in Walker, with hospitalizations rising from 1–2 to 3–4 per 1,000. Conversely, a 5% increase in coverage would keep all counties below 15 cases and 3 hospitalizations per 1,000. The study highlighted that the 2025 West Texas outbreak infected 762 people, hospitalized 99, and caused 2 deaths, underscoring the risk of waning community immunity. The authors noted, 'These events underscore the challenges in maintaining community immunity in the setting of vaccine hesitancy and disruption of routine vaccination programs, including drops in MMR coverage.'

A second study from Johns Hopkins University examined the impact of non‑medical exemption (NME) policies on MMR uptake across 33 states before and during the 2022‑23 and 2023‑24 school years. The authors wrote, 'These outcomes are of particular importance given recently passed and pending state legislation to increase access to vaccination exemptions in over 15 states,' and concluded that evidence‑based policy reform is urgently needed to protect public health.

Both studies emphasize that policy changes affecting vaccine recommendations and exemption laws can have measurable effects on vaccination coverage and outbreak risk.

**The effect of a six-month programme of intradialytic cycling on survival and hospitalisations in people requiring haemodialysis: 5-year follow-up of the CYCLE-HD randomised controlled trial**
The 5‑year follow‑up of the CYCLE‑HD randomised controlled trial examined whether a six‑month intradialytic cycling (IDC) programme affects long‑term clinical outcomes in haemodialysis patients. The analysis found no significant difference between the IDC and control groups for all‑cause mortality, cardiovascular events (a composite of cardiovascular deaths and hospitalisations), all‑cause hospitalisations or hospital length of stay. Age was associated with a 3.2% increased risk of cardiovascular events per additional year, and diabetes with an 89% increased risk. The cohort had a 5‑year mortality of 55%, with 18% of deaths attributable to cardiovascular causes.

The authors compared their results with other exercise trials. The EXCITE trial, which used a six‑month home walking programme, reported a 29% reduction in the composite outcome of hospitalisation and mortality (HR 0.71, 95% CI 0.50–1.00, p = 0.06) at 36 months post‑trial. The DIATT trial, a 12‑month intradialytic exercise programme, showed significant reductions in hospitalisations (p = 0.024) and days in hospital (p = 0.036). Another study reported a 12‑month mortality HR of 0.17 (95% CI 0.04–0.8, p = 0.02) after a six‑month IDC programme, though the confidence interval was wide.

The CYCLE‑HD data indicated a non‑significant 9% reduction in hospitalisations, consistent with earlier findings that IDC is cost‑effective mainly through fewer admissions. A post‑hoc sample‑size calculation suggested that 955 participants would be required to detect a statistically significant 9% reduction in hospitalisations. Limitations include the small sample size, post‑hoc design, lack of sustained exercise after the initial six months, and potential missing hospitalisation data outside the University Hospitals of Leicester.

Overall, the study concludes that a six‑month IDC programme alone does not improve long‑term survival or reduce cardiovascular events or hospitalisations in haemodialysis patients, highlighting the need for larger, adequately powered trials to assess the clinical impact of exercise interventions in this population.
